refined_translation.full_text: O sudden resurrection! O mercy without end! O fire blazing in the forest of all thoughts! Today you came laughing—you came as the prison key! You came to the desperate like God's own bounty and grace! You are the sun's veil, you are hope's very necessity! You are the sought, you are the seeker—both end and beginning! Rising up in hearts, adorning every thought—the self has begged for need, made itself permissible! O soul that gives life without equal! O joy of knowing and doing! Everything else is pretense and fraud—this disease came, that cure! From that fraud we became twisted, enemies of the innocent—sometimes drunk on houris, sometimes drunk on bread and soup! Look! This drunkenness destroys reason! This teaching destroys tradition! For bread and vegetables—so much drama isn't worth it! Scheming throws a hundred colors, throws on Rome, throws on rust—throws us into the middle of war—artificial making no one can see! Rub wine secretly on your soul's ear! Don't make excuses to people! Cry out 'My Lord, deliver me!'—by God, it's all mockery, master! Be silent! I'm too hasty—I ran toward knowledge's feet! Put down the paper! Break the pen! The cupbearer enters—come to prayer!

refined_translation.full_text: O holy birds! Your Love has given them wings—In the circle of longing for You, spirits are drunk with ecstasy! In 'I love not those that set'—yes! Purity from all forms! In the eyes that see beyond sight, You appear every breath! Heaven spins upside down because of You, earth bleeds like an ocean—I won't call You moon, O You who outlast all moons and years! Mountains crack from grief of You—that grief woven into my heart! One drop of blood has found these bounties from Your grace. O support of all chiefs! Count us in that number—You know even heads must have followers trailing behind. You make a master from dust—angels burn with envy! With Your coin, souls turn merchant, wealth trampled underfoot. The one whose wing You are—O his glory, his elevation! The one whose state became this bears beauty marks on his face. Yes, I'm a bad thorn—but thorns bloom for the rose! Even the gold-weigher puts barley on his scales. Thought gave these deeds, dust gave this wealth, Carpet gave these states, states gave these words. World begins in uproar, world ends in earthquake—Love and gratitude with complaint, peace with earthquakes! Shams's seal came as dawn—the royal mark of divine Love's kingdom! The omen of union takes the lead—that Love cast these signs. From 'mercy to the worlds'—see how the dervishes prosper! Robes bright as moon, shawls fragrant as roses. Love is the command 'Be!' and we're just a patch—It's ocean, we're a sip! It brings a hundred proofs while we make arguments. From Love, heaven harmonizes—without Love, stars eclipse! From Love, dal became alif—without Love, alif slouches like dal. Water of life is speech from the knowledge 'from Our presence'—Don't keep your soul empty of it, so it can give birth to deeds! For people of meaning, speech became both general and particular, For people of form, speech became particular and general. If poems were spoken wing by wing, the sea would be pearl—From poetry's rapture, even camels sweetly pull their loads!

translations.scholarly_notes:
**Quranic Allusions:**
- Quran 6:76: I love not those that set
- Quran 21:107: mercy to the worlds
- Quran 18:65: from Our presence

**Sufi Terminology:**
- *طایران قدس* (ṭāyirān-i quds): birds of sanctity - elevated souls or angels who gain spiritual wings through love
- *روحانیان* (rūḥāniyān): spiritual beings, both angels and advanced mystics
- *حال* (ḥāl): mystical state - temporary spiritual condition experienced in the circle of divine yearning
- *سودا* (sawdā): mystical yearning, divine madness, passionate longing for the Beloved
- *غیب بین* (ghayb-bīn): those who see the unseen realm, mystics with spiritual vision
- *درویشان* (darwīshān): dervishes, Sufi practitioners who have embraced spiritual poverty
- *خرقه* (khirqa): Sufi robe, symbolizing initiation and spiritual lineage
- *فنا* (fanā): implied in the dissolution imagery - spiritual annihilation in divine love

**Deliberate Ambiguities:**
- "توقیع شمس": signature of Shams (Shams-i Tabrizi), signature of the sun (divine illumination)
- "یار": divine beloved, Shams-i Tabrizi, any spiritual friend
- "ماه": moon (celestial), beloved's face, spiritual illumination

**Wordplay (Lost in Translation):**
- *حال/قال*: mystical state/speech, condition/saying
- *شمس*: sun, Shams-i Tabrizi
- *دال/الف*: Arabic letters dal/alif, guide/straight
- *افلاک/خاک*: heavens/earth, celestial spheres/dust

**Translation Notes:**
- Verse 2: Quranic reference 6:76 - Abraham's rejection of worship of temporary things
- Verse 11: توقیع شمس could be both 'signature of Shams (Tabrizi)' or 'signature of the sun'
- Verse 12: Quranic reference 21:107 - description of Prophet Muhammad
- Verse 13: Reference to divine command 'kun' (Be!) from Quranic creation verses
- Verse 15: Quranic reference 18:65 - divine knowledge from God's presence
- Verse 17: Final verse uses imagery of poetry as ocean of pearls and mystical journey

refined_translation.full_text: Look at that form! Look at that grace—that stature, those cheeks, hands and feet! Look at that radiance! Look at that moment—that full moon wrapped in silk! Should I call you cypress or garden? Tulip or jasmine? Should I call you candle or golden basin—or the rose dancing before dawn's breath? O Love! You came like a fire-temple taking human form—You ambushed the caravan of my heart! Grant me one moment's peace, O beautiful one! In fire, in my burning, I carry the night until my dawn—O my blessed conqueror, by the face of that Sun of morning light! I whirl around his moon, I greet him without speaking—I throw myself to the ground before him who calls the prayer! Rose-garden of the world! Eye and lamp of the world! And the pain, the scar of the world—when you step into cruelty! I come to pledge my soul—you say 'Don't bother me, go away!' I serve until you accept me—you say 'You fool, come here!' My imagination has joined the fire-drunk lovers—Don't let your face vanish for one moment from our sight! O heart! What happened to your peace? What happened to all your work? What is this that steals your sleep at morning and evening? My heart cried: 'The beauty of his face! Those sorcerer narcissus eyes! Those hyacinth eyebrows! Those sweet ruby lips—what a story!' O Love! You have countless names and titles for everyone—Last night I gave you a new name: pain without medicine! O splendor of my soul—from you! Like a wheel I turn—from you! Send grain, O beloved, so the mill doesn't stand empty! I won't draw another breath! Just speak this verse—enough! This longing has melted my soul—be gentle with us, O our Lord!

stylistic_choices.choice: Used exclamatory 'Look at!' repetition
stylistic_choices.rationale: Creates Rumi's urgent, ecstatic tone of witnessing divine beauty

stylistic_choices.choice: Transformed 'fire-temple' into active metaphor
stylistic_choices.rationale: Preserves Zoroastrian reference while making it visceral—Love as temple incarnate

stylistic_choices.choice: Kept 'calls the prayer' literal
stylistic_choices.rationale: Preserves Islamic prayer context (adhan) essential to Rumi's spiritual landscape

stylistic_choices.choice: Direct dialogue with quoted speech
stylistic_choices.rationale: Captures the intimate, conversational dynamic between lover and Beloved

stylistic_choices.choice: 'fire-drunk lovers' instead of 'fiery lovers'
stylistic_choices.rationale: More vivid—lovers intoxicated by divine fire, classic Rumi imagery

stylistic_choices.choice: 'pain without medicine' for incurable pain
stylistic_choices.rationale: More concrete and desperate—medicine vs. abstract 'cure'

stylistic_choices.choice: Kept 'O our Lord' (rabbana)
stylistic_choices.rationale: Preserves Quranic invocation that ends many suras

refined_translation.tone_notes: Achieved Rumi's ecstatic urgency through exclamations, direct address, and embodied language. The poem moves from visual intoxication through spiritual bewilderment to final surrender, maintaining the passionate intimacy of lover speaking to Beloved throughout.

issues: Line 1: 'wrapped in silk' for 'در قبا' - qaba is more like a robe/coat than silk wrapping
Line 3: 'ambushed' adds aggressive connotation not in 'زده' (struck)
Line 12: 'grain' for 'گندم' is acceptable but 'wheat' would be more precise

translations.scholarly_notes:
**Translation Notes:**
- Verse 1: هنگ could mean 'time' or 'manner/way' - translated as 'time' here
- Verse 2: لگن typically means basin/bowl, possibly referring to a reflecting pool or ceremonial vessel
- Verse 4: شمس الضحی literally means 'sun of the morning light' - a common epithet in Islamic literature
- Verse 5: صلا refers to the call to prayer (adhan)
- Verse 10: Persian poetry conventionally describes beauty using cypress (tall stature), narcissus (eyes), hyacinth (curly hair/eyebrows), ruby (lips)
- Verse 12: The metaphor of mill and wheat refers to spiritual sustenance and continuous divine remembrance
- Verse 13: ربنا is Arabic meaning 'Our Lord' - a Quranic expression
